i actually want to talk
today about death

now most of us do our best to not to
think about death

but there's always part of our
minds that knows
this cant go on forever
part of us always knows

that we're just a doctor's visit away or
a phone call away from being starkly
reminded
with the fact of our own mortality
or of those closest to us

now i'm sure many of you in this room
have experienced this in some form
you must know how uncanny it is
to suddenly
be thrown out of the normal course of your life

and just be given the full time job
of not dying
or caring for someone who is
but the one thing people tend to realize

at moments like this is that they wasted
a lot of time
when life was normal
and it's not just what they, it's not just what they did with their time, it's not just
that they

spent too much time working or or
compulsively checking email
it's that they cared about the wrong things
they regret what they cared about
their attention was bound up in petty concerns
year after year
when life was normal
and this is a paradox of course because
we all know
this epiphany is coming
i mean, don't you know this is coming?
don't you know there's going to come a day
when you'll be sick or someone close to you will die
and you'll look back

at the kinds of things that captured
your attention
and you'll think, "what, what was I doing?"
you know this, and yet if you're like most people,
you'll spend most of your time in life
tacitly presuming you'll live forever
it's like watching a bad movie for the fourth time
or bickering with your spouse
I mean this, these things only makes sense
in light of eternity

there better be a heaven if we're gonna
waste our time like that
there are ways to
really live in the present moment
what what's the alternative?
it is always now

however much you feel you may need to
plan for the future
to anticipate it, to mitigate the risks,
the reality of your life is now
this may sound trite
but it's the truth
it's not quite true as a matter of physics, in fact there is no now

that encompasses the entire universe you
can't talk about an event
being simultaneously
occurring here and one
at the same moment occurring in Andromeda

the truth is, now is not even
well-defined as a matter of neurology because
we know that inputs to the brain

come at different moments and that 
consciousness is built upon layers

of inputs whose timing to have to be
different

are conscious awareness of the present
moment is
in some relevant sense already a memory
but as a matter of conscious experience
the reality of your life
is always now

and i think this is a liberating truth
about the nature of the human mind in

fact i think there's probably nothing
more important to understand
about your mind than that
if you want to be happy
the past is a memory
it's a thought
arising in the present

the future is merely anticipated, it
is another thought
arising now
what we truly have
is this moment
and this
and this
and we spend most of our lives forgetting this truth
repudiating it, fleeing it, overlooking it,
and the horror
is that we succeed
we we've managed to

never really connect with the present
moment and find fulfillment there because we
are we are

continually hoping to become happy in

anticipating what's coming next

comments.text:
Come on, +Sam Harris, you're giving atheists a bad name.

You know perfectly well, that after we die, there's no review of your life 
to score how well you did.

You're trying to portray life as, "we're these beautiful important beings, 
and we'll all going to be destroyed soon. Everything we do between now and 
then is very important!"

That is not true and you know it. Would anyone notice a single grain of 
sand missing from a beach? Our planet isn't even a grain of sand to the 
universe. The laws of physics do not permit us to affect the universe in 
any appreciable way, no matter how clever or creative or kind we are. 
Whatever the purpose of the universe, we have no role whatsoever in its 
outcome.

Atheists aren't depressing because we believe these important beings are 
destroyed. We're depressing because we believe we were never important in 
the first place. Except it actually isn't depressing when you think about 
it.

If nothing we do matters, then we can stop feeling anxious. We can also 
stop feeling anxious by telling ourselves we'll live forever.  The only 
difference is, our insignificance is true, and living forever is just a 
fantasy.

Why should I bother pointing all this out, if none of it matters? Well, 
gotta do *something*.﻿

comments.text:
"Our planet isn't even a grain of sand to the universe."

A universe doesn't look at a planet like a person looks at a grain of sand. 
The universe isn't a person. And, if it was, for all you know, the optimum 
"care size" of the universe is not a human, a planet, or a grain of sand, 
but at the scale of, say, a cat. There's some kind of logical fallacy going 
on there - to relate our size relative to the universe to our level of 
importance. 

"Whatever the purpose of the universe, we have no role whatsoever in its 
outcome."

To be specific, we *must* have a role in the outcome, since we are a part 
of it. But more generally speaking, we simply do not know if we will have a 
significant impact on the universe. We may go on to colonize life 
throughout the universe. That would make us significant on a universal 
scale, in my opinion at least.

But I don't think Sam was arguing we are "important" in the grand scheme of 
things. It seemed like he was saying we should put more importance on our 
own lives and our experiences and to not squander them away on pettiness. 
Again, not because your life is any more important than the next guy's, or 
the next galaxy's, but because it's your life.

I see what your saying though, Jeff, but I just don't think a sense of awe 
and marveling at things in our lives, like Sam was doing, should have to be 
incompatible with a secular world view.

+Dois Koh Well, luckily the top link/auto-play leads right into the 
original talk (which you're right- it's amazing and I could never 
completely encapsulate its message). 

My goal with these videos is not to replace to the original content (which 
is why I to take a lot care in making sure everything is properly cited, in 
chronological order, so people can look up the original works when they 
want to explore the original content further). The goal has been to make 
videos that showcase the incredible works of very smart people, in a way 
that is easily digestible and may even make the viewer want to learn about 
these scientists/philosophers further. 

On a related note, after this video was released, Sam Harris actually 
started uploading sound bites of various topics to his soundcloud/website 
for the sole purpose of making it easier for editors to use his talks in 
the future.

A profound, simple and slippery truth. Easy to understand, hard to do. We 
are biologically hardwired to examine our past and worry about the future 
to increase our odds of survival. If blissfully enlightened individuals 
existed among our ancestors, they were probably more likely to be eaten by 
saber-tooth tigers and starve to death before they could procreate. But 
that doesn't mean that we can't practice mindfulness, become better at 
dwelling in the now and reap a great increase in well-being and happiness. 
One of the best ways of doing this is practicing meditation, which should 
(imo) be taught to all school children. I believe most religions attempt 
doing this through prayer and contemplation, but Zen Buddhism comes closest 
to the truth Harris is talking about...﻿

comments.text:
"We do not rest satisfied with the present. We anticipate the future as too 
slow in coming, as if in order to hasten its course; or we recall the past, 
to stop its too rapid flight. So imprudent are we that we wander in the 
times which are not ours, and do not think of the only one which belongs to 
us; and so idle are we that we dream of those times which are no more, and 
thoughtlessly overlook that which alone exists. For the present is 
generally painful to us. We conceal it from our sight, because it troubles 
us; and if it be delightful to us, we regret to see it pass away. We try to 
sustain it by the future, and think of arranging matters which are not in 
our power, for a time which we have no certainty of reaching.

Let each one examine his thoughts, and he will find them all occupied with 
the past and the future. We scarcely ever think of the present; and if we 
think of it, it is only to take light from it to arrange the future. The 
present is never our end. The past and the present are our means; the 
future alone is our end. So we never live, but we hope to live; and, as we 
are always preparing to be happy, it is inevitable we should never be so."

- Blaise Pascal's Pensées, Thoughts on Mind and on Style, Aphorism # 172﻿

I'm surprised at how many who confuse this with religiousness, even a few 
Harris "fans".

This is far from it. This is a scientific analysis of other people's report 
of their subjective experience when their life comes to an end or in 
struggle. It's perfectly possible to objectively speak about people's 
subjective experiences.

And those who think he is promoting halting ambition, planning and working 
towards a goal, etc. needs to listen to the premise again.

PS: And he says "many", "a lot", "some", not "all", so if it doesn't apply 
to you that's great, you are among the rest.﻿
